context: Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) transports the α-amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate with the generation of pyruvate and glutamate. Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) catalyzes the transfer of α-amino groups from aspartate to α-ketoglutarate with the formation of oxaloacetate and glutamate. The transfer of α-amino groups from the branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, and valine) to α-ketoglutarate, generating their cognate branched-chain keto acids (α-ketoisocaproate, α-keto-β-methylglutarate, and α -ketoisovalerate, respectively) and glutamate, is performed by branched-chain amino acids aminotransferase (BCAT). Pyridoxal phosphate, the functional form of vitamin B6, is a cofactor for aminotransferases reactions.Urea cycle enzymes Human hepatocytes utilize two end-products of metabolism, ammonia and carbon dioxide (under the form of bicarbonate), to generate some amino acids (citrulline, arginine, and ornithine) through a chain of reactions referred to as ornithine cycle, Krebs–Henseleit cycle or urea cycle (Fig. 6 ). Urea and fumarate are produced while aspartate is consumed as a result of the cycle functioning. Activity of the mitochondrial isoenzyme of carbonic anhydrase is thought to be required to supply bicarbonate from carbon dioxide, as urea synthesis in healthy humans is inhibited by acetazolamide. Amino groups derived from various amino acids are funneled by hepatic aminotransferases to glutamate, which is deaminated in the mitochondria by glutamate dehydrogenase, producing free ammonium ions and α-ketoglutarate.
